sen.j: 禅林寺（ぜんりんじ）は、京都市左京区永観堂町にある浄土宗西山禅林寺派総本山の寺院。
sen.e: Zenrin-ji Temple, located in Eikando-cho, Sakyo Ward, Kyoto City, is the headquarters of the Seizan-Zenrinji branch of the Pure Land Sect.
Zenrin-ji Temple, located in Eikando-cho, Sakyo Ward, Kyoto City, is the headquarters of the Seizan-Zenrin-ji branch of the Pure Land Sect.
Zenrin-ji Temple, located in Eikando-cho, Sakyo Ward, Kyoto City, is the headquarters of the Seizan-Zenrin-ji branch of the Pure Land Sect.

sen.j: 一般には通称の永観堂（えいかんどう）の名で知られる。
sen.e: It is commonly known by the name 'Eikan-do'.
It is commonly known by the name 'Eikan-do.'
It is commonly known by the name Eikan-do.

sen.j: 山号を聖衆来迎山（しょうじゅらいごうさん）、院号を無量寿院と称する。
sen.e: The honorific mountain prefix is 'Shoju-raigousan' and its title is 'Muryojuin'.
The honorific mountain prefix is 'Shoju-raigousan' and its title is 'Muryojuin.'
The honorific mountain prefix is Shoju-raigosan and its title is Muryojuin.
sen.cmt: raigousan→raigosan ヘボン式原文に「」のない' 'を削除

sen.j: 本尊は阿弥陀如来、開基（創立者）は、空海の高弟の真紹僧都である。
sen.e: The temple was founded by Kukai's leading disciple Shinjo Sozu and is dedicated to the principal image Amida Nyorai.
sen.cmt: ・Kukai: http://dic.yahoo.co.jp/dsearch?enc=UTF-8&p=空海&dtype=0&dname=0na&stype=0&pagenum=1&index=05742604934000・Shinjo Sozu: http://kotobank.jp/word/真紹・principal image: 英辞郎 on the WEB
sen.e: The temple was founded by Kukai's leading disciple Shinjo Sozu and is dedicated to the principal image Amida Nyorai.
The temple was founded by Kukai's leading disciple Shinjo Sozu and is dedicated to the principal image Amida Nyorai.

sen.j: 当寺は紅葉の名所として知られ、古くより「秋はもみじの永観堂」といわれる。
sen.e: It is famous for its red autumn leaves and has long been called 'Autumn leaf Eikan-do'.
It is famous for its Momiji (red autumn maple leaves) and has long been called 'Autumn maple leaf Eikan-do.'
sen.cmt: Momiji, mapleを補足。 ピリオドを移動。
sen.e: It is famous for its Momiji (red autumn maple leaves) and has long been called 'Autumn maple leaf Eikan-do.'

sen.j: また、京都に3箇所あった勧学院（学問研究所）の一つでもあり、古くから学問（論義）が盛んである。
sen.e: Additionally, it is one of Kyoto's 3 Kangakuin (educational institutions) and has been a prominent center of learning since ancient times.
Additionally, it is one of Kyoto's 3 Kangakuin (educational institutions) and has been a prominent center of learning since ancient times.
Additionally, it is one of Kyoto's three Kangakuin (educational institutions) and has been a prominent center of learning since ancient times.

sen.j: 空海（弘法大師）の高弟である僧都・真紹が、都における実践道場の建立を志し、五智如来を本尊とする寺院を建立したのが起源である。
sen.e: The temple's origin lies in the temple dedicated to the Five Wisdom Buddhas founded by Kukai's (Kobo-daishi) leading disciple Shinjo Sozu after aspiring to establish a practical training site in the capital.
sen.cmt: ・Kukai: http://dic.yahoo.co.jp/dsearch?enc=UTF-8&p=空海&dtype=0&dname=0na&stype=0&pagenum=1&index=05742604934000・Kobo-daishi: http://dic.yahoo.co.jp/dsearch?enc=UTF-8&p=弘法大師&stype=1&dtype=0・Five Wisdom Buddhas: http://kotobank.jp/word/五智如来
sen.e: The temple's origin lies in the temple dedicated to the Five Wisdom Buddhas founded by Kukai's (Kobo-daishi) leading disciple Shinjo Sozu after aspiring to establish a practical training site in the capital.

The temple's origin lies in the temple dedicated to the Five Wisdom Buddhas founded by Kukai's (Kobo-daishi) leading disciple Shinjo Sozu after aspiring to establish a practical training site in the capital.

sen.j: 真紹は仁寿3年（853年）、歌人・文人であった故・藤原関雄の邸宅跡を買い取り、ここを寺院とすることにした。
sen.e: In the year 853, Shinjo purchased the mansion of the deceased poet and author FUJIWARA no Sekio and converted it to a temple.
In the year 853, Shinjo purchased the mansion of the deceased poet and author FUJIWARA no Sekio and converted it to a temple.
In the year 853, Shinjo purchased the mansion of the deceased poet and author FUJIWARA no Sekio and converted it to a temple.

sen.j: 当時の京都ではみだりに私寺を建立することは禁じられており、10年後の貞観 (日本)5年（863年）、当時の清和天皇より定額寺としての勅許と「禅林寺」の寺号を賜わって公認の寺院となった。
sen.e: The construction of private temples was forbidden in Kyoto at the time, however, and so it was not until ten years later in 863, when formal Imperial approval was granted by Emperor Seiwa, that Zenrin-ji Temple became officially recognized.

The construction of private temples was forbidden in Kyoto at the time, however, and so it was not until ten years later in 863, when formal Imperial approval as Jogaku-ji Temple was granted by Emperor Seiwa, that Zenrin-ji Temple became officially recognized.

The construction of private temples was forbidden in Kyoto at the time, however, and so it was not until ten years later in 863, when formal Imperial approval as Jogaku-ji Temple was granted by Emperor Seiwa, that Zenrin-ji Temple became officially recognized.

sen.j: 当初真言宗寺院として出発した禅林寺は、中興の祖とされる7世住持の律師・永観 (僧)（ようかん、1033年 - 1111年）の頃から浄土教色を強めていく。
sen.e: Though originally devoted to the Shingon Sect, the temple began a shift towards the Pure Land Sect under 7th chief priest and restoration patriarch Yokan (1033-1111).
Though originally devoted to the Shingon Sect, the temple began a shift towards the Pure Land Sect under 7th chief priest and restoration patriarch Yokan (1033-1111).
Though originally devoted to the Shingon Sect, the temple began a shift towards the Pure Land Sect under seventh chief priest and restoration patriarch Yokan (1033 - 1111).
sen.cmt: 7th→seventh 他フィアルと統一ハイフンの前後にスペース挿入

sen.j: 永観は文章博士（もんじょうはかせ）源国経の子として生まれ、11歳で禅林寺の深観に弟子入りする。
sen.e: Yokan was the son of Monjo-hakase MINAMOTO no Kunitsune and entered Zenrin-ji Temple aged 11 as the disciple of Jinkan.
sen.cmt: ・MINAMOTO no Kunitsune: http://100.yahoo.co.jp/detail/永観（ようかん）/・Jinkan: http://kotobank.jp/word/深観
sen.e: Yokan was the son of Monjo-hakase MINAMOTO no Kunitsune and entered Zenrin-ji Temple aged 11 as the disciple of Jinkan.
Yokan was the son of Monjo-hakase MINAMOTO no Kunitsune and entered Zenrin-ji Temple aged 11 as the disciple of Jinkan.

sen.j: 当初、南都六宗のうちの三論宗、法相宗を学ぶが、やがて熱烈な阿弥陀信者となり、日課一万遍の念仏を欠かさぬようになる。
sen.e: At that time, he studied under the Sanron Sect and Hosso Sect of the Nanto rokushu (six sects of Nanto) but eventually became a passionate devotee of the Amida Buddha and would not fail to recite the Nembutsu (Buddhist invocation) ten thousand times every day.
sen.cmt: ・Nanto rokushu (six sects of Nanto): http://dic.yahoo.co.jp/dsearch?enc=UTF-8&p=法相宗&stype=1&dtype=0
sen.e: At that time, he studied under the Sanron Sect and Hosso Sect of the Nanto rokushu (six sects of Nanto) but eventually became a passionate devotee of the Amida Buddha and would not fail to recite the Nembutsu (Buddhist invocation) ten thousand times every day.

At that time, he studied under the Sanron Sect and Hosso Sect of the Nanto rokushu (six sects of Nanto) but eventually became a passionate devotee of the Amida Buddha and would not fail to recite the Nembutsu (Buddhist invocation) ten thousand times every day.

sen.j: 師深観の跡を受けて禅林寺に入るのは延久4年（1072年）のことである。
sen.e: In 1072 he took over the role of his master.
In 1072 he took over the role of his master and entered Zenrin-ji Temple.
sen.cmt: "禅林寺に入る"が抜けている。
sen.e: In 1072 he took over the role of his master and entered Zenrin-ji Temple.

sen.j: 永観は人々に念仏を勧め、また、禅林寺内に薬王院を設けて、病人救済などの慈善事業も盛んに行なった。
sen.e: Yokan encouraged people to recite the Nemutsu and established a Yakuo-in on the temple grounds, which took care of the sick and organized charitable work.
Yokan encouraged people to recite the Nembutsu and established a Yakuo-in on the temple grounds, which took care of the sick and organized charitable work.
Yokan encouraged people to recite the Nembutsu and established a Yakuo-in on the temple grounds, which took care of the sick and organized charitable work.

sen.j: 永観は、今日の社会福祉活動の先駆者といえるであろう。
sen.e: It could be said that Yokan was the forefather of today's social welfare activities.
It could be said that Yokan was the forefather of today's social welfare activities.
It could be said that Yokan was the forefather of today's social welfare activities.

sen.j: 禅林寺を永観堂と呼ぶのは、この永観律師が住したことに由来する。
sen.e: It was due to the role of chief priest Yokan that Zenrin-ji Temple came to be called 'Eikan-do'.
It was due to the role of chief priest Yokan that Zenrin-ji Temple came to be called 'Eikan-do.'
It was due to the role of chief priest Yokan that Zenrin-ji Temple came to be called Eikan-do.

sen.j: なお、「永観堂」は普通「えいかんどう」と読むが、「永観」という僧の名は「ようかん」と読むのが正しいとされている。
sen.e: The temple name it is usually read 'Eikan-do' but it is considered correct to read the monk's name 'Yokan'.
The temple name it is usually read 'Eikan-do' but it is considered correct to read the monk's name 'Yokan.'
The temple name is usually read 'Eikan-do' (永観堂) but it is considered correct to read the monk's name 'Yokan (永観).'
sen.cmt: it削除漢字が同じであることを示すため、漢字名を補足

sen.j: 禅林寺の本尊阿弥陀如来立像は、顔を左（向かって右）に曲げた特異な姿の像である。
sen.e: The principal image standing statue of Amida Nyorai is unusual in that it is looking over its left shoulder (right when looking face on).
sen.cmt: ・principal image: 英辞郎 on the WEB
sen.e: The principal image standing statue of Amida Nyorai is unusual in that it is looking over its left shoulder (right when looking face on).
The principal image standing statue of Amida Nyorai is unusual in that it is looking over its left shoulder (right when looking face on).

sen.j: この像については次のような伝承がある。
sen.e: There is a legend regarding this statue.
There is a legend regarding this statue.
There is a following legend regarding this statue.

sen.j: 永保2年（1082年）、当時50歳の永観が日課の念仏を唱えつつ、阿弥陀如来の周囲を行道していたところ、阿弥陀如来が須弥壇から下り、永観と一緒に行道を始めた。
sen.e: It says that 1082 when Yokan, aged 50, was reciting the daily Nembutsu as he walked around the statue, Amida Nyorai came to life, stepped down from its dais and began to walk round with Yokan.
It says that 1082 when Yokan, aged 50, was reciting the daily Nembutsu as he walked around the statue, Amida Nyorai came to life, stepped down from its dais and began to walk round with Yokan.
It says that 1082 when Yokan, aged 50, was reciting the daily Nembutsu as he walked around the statue, Amida Nyorai came to life, stepped down from its dais and began to walk round with Yokan.

sen.j: 驚いた永観が歩みを止めると、阿弥陀如来は振り返って一言、「永観遅し」と言ったという。
sen.e: It is said that when the surprised Yokan stopped walking, Amida Nyorai looked over its shoulder and said to him "Yokan, you are too slow."
It is said that when the surprised Yokan stopped walking, Amida Nyorai looked over its shoulder and said to him 'Yokan, you are too slow.'
It is said that when the surprised Yokan stopped walking, Amida Nyorai looked over its shoulder and said to him 'Yokan, you are too slow.'

sen.j: 本寺の阿弥陀如来像はそれ以来首の向きが元に戻らず、そのままの姿で安置されているのだという。
sen.e: The story goes that, ever since then, the posture of the statue of has remained in that position.
The story goes that, ever since then, the posture of the statue of has remained in that position.
The story goes that, ever since then, the posture of the statue of the temple has remained in that position.

sen.j: 禅林寺12世の僧都・静遍（じょうへん、1166年 - 1224年）は、当初真言宗の僧であったが、後に法然に帰依し、念仏門に入った。
sen.e: The twelfth chief priest Johen (1166-1224) was originally a Shingon Sect monk but became a disciple of Honen and devoted to Nembutsu.
The twelfth chief priest Johen (1166-1224) was originally a Shingon Sect monk but became a disciple of Honen and entered Nembutsu-mon (Pure Land School).
The twelfth chief priest Johen (1166 - 1224) was originally a Shingon Sect monk but became a disciple of Honen and entered Nembutsu-mon (Pure Land School).
sen.cmt: ハイフンの前後にスペース挿入

sen.j: 法然の高弟の證空（西山）も、静遍の後を嗣いで当寺に住持したと伝えられている。
sen.e: It is said that Honen's leading disciple Shoku (Seizan) succeeded Johen to become the temple's chief priest.
It is said that Honen's leading disciple Shoku (Seizan) succeeded Johen to become the temple's chief priest.
It is said that Honen's leading disciple Shoku (Seizan) succeeded Johen to become the temple's chief priest.

sen.j: 證空の門弟の浄音の時代に、禅林寺は真言宗から浄土宗西山派（小坂流）の寺院となり、揺るぎのない念仏道場とされた。
sen.e: Under Shoku's disciple, Zenrin-ji Temple went from being devoted to the Shingon Sect to the Seizan branch of the Pure Land Sect and became a firm Nembutsu meditation center.
Under Shoku's disciple, Jo-on, Zenrin-ji Temple went from being devoted to the Shingon Sect to the Seizan branch (Kosaka group) of the Pure Land Sect and became a firm Nembutsu meditation center.
Under Shoku's disciple, Jo-on, Zenrin-ji Temple went from being devoted to the Shingon Sect to the Seizan branch (Kosaka group) of the Pure Land Sect and became a firm Nembutsu meditation center.

sen.j: 境内には地形の高低差を生かして多くの建物が建ち、それらの間は渡り廊下でつながれている。
sen.e: The different elevations within the Zenrin-ji Temple precinct have been utilized to construct many buildings which are connected by covered walkways.
The different elevations within the Zenrin-ji Temple precinct have been utilized to construct many buildings which are connected by covered walkways.
The different elevations within the Zenrin-ji Temple precinct have been utilized to construct many buildings which are connected by covered walkways.

sen.j: 総門－江戸時代末期の建築。
sen.e: Somon (main gate): Constructed during the late Edo period.
Somon (main gate): Constructed during the late Edo period.
Somon (main gate): Constructed during the late Edo period.

sen.j: 「高麗門」と呼ばれる形式である。
sen.e: This type of gate is known as a 'Koraimon',
This type of gate is known as a 'Koraimon.'

sen.e: This type of gate is known as a 'Koraimon.'

sen.j: 中門－延享元年（1744年）の建築。
sen.e: Chumon (inner gate): Constructed in 1744.
Chumon (inner gate): Constructed in 1744.
Chumon (inner gate): Constructed in 1744.

sen.j: 「薬医門」と呼ばれる形式である。
sen.e: This type of gate is known as a 'Yakuimon'.
This type of gate is known as a 'Yakuimon.'
This type of gate is known as a 'Yakuimon.'

sen.j: 「高麗門」「薬医門」ともに、寺院建築よりは城郭、大名屋敷などに多く見られる形式である。
sen.e: Both Koraimon and Yakuimon gates are seen far more often at castles and the mansions of Daimyo than temples.
Both Koraimon and Yakuimon gates are seen far more often at castles and the mansions of Daimyo than temples.
Both Koraimon and Yakuimon gates are seen far more often at castles and the mansions of Daimyo than temples.

sen.j: 御影堂－1912年（大正元年）に完成した総ケヤキ造の仏堂。
sen.e: Miei-do (Founder's Hall): Completed in 1912 and made completely from zelkova wood.
Miei-do (Founder's Hall): Completed in 1912 and made completely from zelkova wood.
Miei-do (Founder's Hall): Completed in 1912 and made completely from zelkova wood.

sen.j: 宗祖法然を祀る堂で、本尊を安置する阿弥陀堂よりも規模が大きい。
sen.e: Enshrines Pure Land Sect founder Honen and is larger than the Amida Hall.
Enshrines Pure Land Sect founder Honen and is larger than the Amida Hall, which enshrines the principal image.

sen.e: Enshrines Pure Land Sect founder Honen and is larger than the Amida Hall, which enshrines the principal image.

sen.j: 阿弥陀堂－御影堂より一段高い敷地に位置する。
sen.e: Amida-do (Amida Hall): Seated on a location slightly higher than the Miei-do.

sen.j: 本尊の「顧り（みかえり）阿弥陀」像（重文）を安置する。

sen.e: Tahoto (two-storey pagoda): Situated at the highest point in the compound and is a visually significant location.

sen.j: 1928年（昭和3年）、篤志家の寄付で建設された。
sen.e: Constructed in 1928 using donations.
Constructed in 1928 using the voluntary contributions of benefactors.

sen.j: 方丈－「方丈」は禅宗寺院特有の建物で、他宗ではあまり見かけないものだが、禅林寺の方丈は、平面、立面ともに禅宗寺院の方丈と同形式の建物である。
sen.e: Hojo (Abbot's Quarters): Hojo are particular to Zen temples and rarely seen in those of other sects but Zenrin-ji Temple's hojo is just like that of a Zen temple.
Hojo (Abbot's Quarters): Hojo are particular to Zen temples and rarely seen in those of other sects but Zenrin-ji Temple's hojo is just like that of a Zen temple.
Hojo (Abbot's Quarters): Hojo are particular to Zen temples and rarely seen in those of other sects but Zenrin-ji Temple's hojo is just like that of a Zen temple in both plan view and elevation view.
sen.cmt: in both plan view and elevation view の訳を補足

sen.j: 寺伝では永正年間（1504－1521）、後柏原天皇によって建てられたというが、実際の建築は江戸時代に降るものとみられる。
sen.e: Its construction is said to have been ordered by Emperor Go-Kashiwabara during the Eisho era (1504-1521), but was actually not built until the Edo period.
Its construction is said to have been ordered by Emperor Go-Kashiwabara during the Eisho era (1504-1521), but was actually not built until the Edo period.
Its construction is said to have been ordered by Emperor Go-Kashiwabara during the Eisho era (1504 - 1521), but was in fact not built until the Edo period.

sen.j: 木造阿弥陀如来立像（みかえり阿弥陀）－「みかえり阿弥陀」の通称で知られる、頭部を左（向かって右）に向けた特異な姿の像。
sen.e: Wooden standing of Amida Nyorai (Mikaeri Amida): This unique statue commonly known as 'Mikaeri Amida' is looking over its left shoulder (right when looking face on).
Wooden standing of Amida Nyorai (Mikaeri Amida): This unique statue commonly known as 'Mikaeri Amida' is looking over its left shoulder (right when looking face on).

sen.j: 像高77センチ。
sen.e: It is 77cm tall.
It is 77cm tall.
It is 77 cm tall.
sen.cmt: 単位の前にスペース挿入

sen.j: かつては鎌倉時代の作とされたこともあったが、作風、構造等の特色から、平安時代末期、12世紀頃の作と見るのが妥当である。
sen.e: It used to be believed to date from the Kamakura period but characteristics such as its style and composition make it now thought to have been carved somewhat earlier in the 12th century in the late Heian period.

It used to be believed to date from the Kamakura period but characteristics such as its style and composition make it now thought to have been carved somewhat earlier in the 12th century in the late Heian period.

It used to be believed to date from the Kamakura period but characteristics such as its style and composition make it now thought to have been carved somewhat earlier in the 12th century in the late Heian period.

sen.j: この種の「みかえり阿弥陀」の作例は中国にもあり（四川省安岳円覚洞16号窟、宋時代）、日本では山形県善光寺像など、鎌倉時代以降の作例が若干知られている。
sen.e: A few examples of post Kamakura period 'Mikaeri Amida' statues similar to this are known in China (Sichuan's 16th cave of Enkakuto, Song Dynasty) and in Japan's Zenko-ji Temple, Yamagata Prefecture.
A few examples of post Kamakura period 'Mikaeri Amida' statues similar to this are known in China (Sichuan's 16th cave of Enkakuto, Song Dynasty) and in Japan's Zenko-ji Temple, Yamagata Prefecture.
